description: From Middle French catapulte, from Latin catapulta, from Ancient Greek καταπέλτης (katapéltēs), from κατά (katá, “downwards, into, against”) + πάλλω (pállō, “I poise or sway a missile before it is thrown”).

entries.meaning: A device or weapon for throwing or launching large objects.
A mechanical aid on aircraft carriers designed to help airplanes take off from the flight deck.
An instance of firing a missile from a catapult.
(figuratively) An instance of firing something, as if from a catapult.

verbs.description: catapult (third-person singular simple present catapults, present participle catapulting, simple past and past participle catapulted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fire a missile from a catapult.
(transitive) To fire or launch something, as if from a catapult.
(transitive) To increase the status of something rapidly.
examples: The candidate selection for running mate has catapulted her to the national scene.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be fired from a catapult or as if from a catapult.
(intransitive) To have one's status increased rapidly.
examples: She catapulted to the national scene following her selection by the candidate.
